awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: GP-IMPACT: Ambassadors for STEM Training to Enhance Participation (A-STEP)
awd_abstract_narration:
Geoscientists work on the front lines of issues affecting human communities worldwide, requiring an educated public positioned to help decision-makers understand Earth's complex workings and ensure the safety of its billions of inhabitants. Expanding diversity and inclusivity in the geosciences is critical as decision-making informed by geosciences is a matter of both social justice and critical national need. Recent research on social vulnerability, particularly the vulnerability of communities to extreme natural events based on social factors such as income, race, ethnicity, and housing, finds that communities of color are often among those most vulnerable to these natural events. To address this challenge head-on, the Ambassadors for STEM Training to Enhance Participation (A-STEP) program will provide a transformative seagoing experience to cohorts of students from underrepresented communities who will be equipped with both solid science background and science communication skills. This experience will broaden perspectives on the role of the oceans as a driver of global and environmental change and is expected to empower ambassadors to communicate that change within their own diverse communities. The project will leverage transits of U.S.-operated marine research vessels to train diverse STEM and non-STEM students in science communication. Under the guidance of instructors and science mentors, these students will become effective ambassadors to disseminate exciting and relevant geoscience information across broad audiences.  
 
The goals of the A-STEP project are to: (1) Raise the profile of geosciences and geoscience-related careers among under-represented groups nationwide; (2) Produce a series of engaging multimedia products to contribute towards this goal; (3) Draw from scientific ocean drilling and related research to develop educational storyboard modules aimed at K-12 audiences showing the impacts of global change on marine and terrestrial systems; and (4) Contribute to increased diversity of knowledge across geoscience-related fields and career choices by drawing greater attention to the relevance of climate and environmental change for all citizens.
To achieve these goals, cohorts of 16 students annually from talented pools of STEM and non-STEM majors will join scientists and science education/communication professionals on short transit cruises on the JOIDES Resolution and UNOLS vessels. Students will learn first-hand in the scientifically-rich environment of an oceanographic cruise the significance of data gleaned from marine sediments, marine organisms, marine pollution, water chemistry, weather and climate patterns, and seafloor dynamics. Subsequently, these newly-minted ambassadors will be deployed across their communities and the nation to transmit the importance and relevance of geoscience information and careers, create innovative products and presentations about their experiences, and make linkages between climate and environmental change and people's daily lives. A-STEP cohorts will become a rich nationwide resource for inspiring the next generation of geoscientists. As ambassadors tasked with promoting STEM knowledge and careers, program participants will bring meaning and value to information, demonstrating how climate and environmental change is affecting all citizens, urban and rural. Citizens with few direct connections to science and scientists, who unfortunately are disproportionately African American, Latino, and Native American communities, are often more vulnerable to misinformation and will especially benefit from interactions with A-STEP students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A major outcome of this project was the involvement of many participants (researchers, graduate and undergraduate students, and professional collaborators), all of whom were invaluable in promoting and advancing the key objectives of the program. Additionally, K-12 students, family members and community members benefited from the science dissemination efforts of the ambassadors. Via these efforts, the project accomplished the central objectives of raising the profile of geosciences and bio/geoscience-related careers among under-represented groups; producing a series of charismatic multimedia learning tools to contribute towards this ideal; developing educational modules aimed at K-12 learners; demonstrating the impacts of global change on marine and terrestrial systems; and contributing to increased access to knowledge across bio/geoscience-related fields of study and career choices by drawing greater attention to the relevance of global environmental change for all citizens.

 

Beyond this, the impact of these outcomes can be amplified by an active effort of dissemination on the part of all A-STEP investigators and their laboratories.

 

The educational materials that we developed were tested both nationally and internationally. In all these instances, educators or experts in communication and pedagogy provided constructive feedback. The Power Point Presentations that we prepared were made available not only to A-STEP participants, but to other users as well.

Of special significance was the effort to organize A-STEP workshops in venues in rural communities of Mexico, Peru and Costa Rica, thanks to the establishment of partnerships with institutions, colleagues and students from those localities. The implementation of workshops in the Tajin Region of Northern Veracruz, for example, was a collaboration with the University of Veracruz and the local agency of the National Institutes of Anthropology and History enjoyed massive attendance from students, educators, family members, and members of the community. Similar results were obtained from efforts with the rural communities near the City of Cuzco, Peru. The workshops in Peru attracted a large audience of K-12 students, family members and members of the general public.

 

I wish to also highlight the production of The History of Life video, in which the connections between land and sea are highlighted. This video, and its accompanying learning activity was shared with multiple communities. In order to increase equitable access to this learning tool, this video was translated both into American Sign Language and Spanish.

 

EJ scholarly work has documented the social disproportionality in the impact of the harmful effects of global change. For example, marginalized communities contribute the least to greenhouse emissions and yet they are being (and will likely continue to be) the most affected by climate change. Similarly, the availability of opportunities to access nature suffers from disproportionality, with underserved populations experiencing limited opportunities to this environmental service. For this reason, a key outcome of the A-STEP effort has been to bring these topics into the presentations and activities we shared as broadly as possible.

 

 

Our A-STEP program actively took advantage of Stanford’s Jasper Ridge Biological Preserve and provided guided tours whereby we focused the experience not only on the opportunity to access nature (an aspect that the literature increasingly shows is of high value in mental health), but also on examining, hands-on, the principal elements of global change (climate, biodiversity loss, disruptions to land-sea-connections) and the significance of science to address those challenges of our times.     

 

Lastly, the roundtable discussions we generated with experts of different fields provided insights for teachers and educators to take advantage of the activities and learning tools we developed in order to reflect and perhaps implement modifications or adaptations of such materials according to their particular educational contexts. Going forward, we hope that the efforts and accomplishments of this program could lead to greater incursion/representation into STEM fields by underserved students, and that they will continue to be champions to address the challenges of global environmental change.
